history.content:
The circuits in 16B is only a small portion of the class. It was just the first couple of weeks when I took it. You could get away with just reviewing the 16A circuits a few weeks before you take 16B. As for CS 70, my recommendation would be to practice exam questions with every topic you lean. For example, if you just did confidence intervals in lecture and discussion, then go through a few past exams and do any questions pertaining to confidence intervals. This would be more helpful for getting good grades on the exams, in my opinion, especially since many exam questions are much different than the homework questions are.

=========================

If I were you, I would take Math 55 for either a letter grade or p/np, and then take cs70. Math 55 is a subset of 70, but covers a lot of the same material.

===========

I thought you wouldn't get credit for CS70 after Math 55(https://www2.eecs.berkeley.edu/Courses/CS70/). This reason is exactly why I didn't mention Math 55.

==========

Ah in that case, don't take math 55 before CS70. You could audit Math 55 or CS 70 a semester beforehand (go to lectures and do hw)!

The circuits in 16B is only a small portion of the class. It was just the first couple of weeks when I took it. You could get away with just reviewing the 16A circuits a few weeks before you take 16B. As for CS 70, my recommendation would be to practice exam questions with every topic you lean. For example, if you just did confidence intervals in lecture and discussion, then go through a few past exams and do any questions pertaining to confidence intervals. This would be more helpful for getting good grades on the exams, in my opinion, especially since many exam questions are much different than the homework questions are.

This would be more helpful for getting good grades on the exams, in my opinion, especially since many exam questions are much different than the homework questions are.

If I were you, I would take Math 55 for either a letter grade or p/np, and then take cs70. Math 55 is a subset of 70, but covers a lot of the same material.

The circuits in 16B is only a small portion of the class. It was just the first couple of weeks when I took it. You could get away with just reviewing the 16A circuits a few weeks before you take 16B. As for CS 70, my recommendation would be to practice exam questions with every topic you lean. For example, if you just did confidence intervals in lecture and discussion, then go through a few past exams and do any questions pertaining to confidence intervals. This would be more helpful for getting good grades on the exams, in my opinion, especially since many exam questions are much different than the homework questions are.

Hi!

I'm a second year, intended CS. I have only CS70 left of the prereqs and I need an A- to meet the gpa cutoff. I'm currently in EE16A, CS 61C, and 2 other classes. I have a few questions and it'd be nice to get anyone's feedback.

For those who have done well in CS70(gotten A- or higher), how did you prepare for the class or what did you do that made you really successful? What were you're "mathematical maturity"level and what classes did you take previously(AP/IB classes, community )? I'm planning on taking the IMT decal this semester if I get in, and auditing CS70 in the spring 2019 so I can take it in the summer 2019. 

This might sound a bit ridiculous, but would you recommend taking Stat 134 to prepare for CS70? It's an upper division class for a lower division class. I hear from others that 134 covers about 80% of the stats in CS70, but I'm aware that 134 is also a very intense course. 

Has anyone taken EE16B and EE16A in non-consecutvie semester? In other words, did anyone take EE16A, then EE16B a year later? How was your experience doing this? I'm considering this to focus on declaring cs, but I don't know if I'll feel completely lost in EE16B, since the circuits unit from 16A continue on to 16B.
history.subject: Questions regarding GPA Cutoff for Lower Division Classes
